Comments: Very honest and personal look of what it meant for three women growing up in Bronzeville from the 60's through the early 2000's.
Title: Three Girls from Bronzeville: A Uniquely American Memoir of Race, Fate, and Sisterhood
Author: Dawn Turner

Comments: An awesome story reminiscent of the movie Ground Hogs Day that will have you thinking about the life choices you didn't make and who you might have been.
Title: Midnight Library
Author: Matt Haig

Comments: An illustrated series that follows the Big Bad Wolf and his compatriots as they struggle to do good deeds despite their reputations.
Title: Bad Guys Box Set: Books 1-5
Author: Aaron Blabey

Comments: (FYI: it says special order on the website)  blurb: Endearing fish-out-of-water story about kids trying to fit in, stand out, and make it through middle school. One of this prolific author's most popular titles (but he's got lots of other good ones, too!)
Title: Schooled
Author: Gordon Korman

Comments: Alcatraz vs. the Evil Librarians is a fun middle reader fantasy series that follows a teenage boy and his unique family as the work to protective the world from nefarious librarians bent on ruling the world by controlling the flow of knowledge. The books are written in first person with lots of self-deprecating humor.
Title: Alcatraz vs. the Evil Librarians
Author: Brandon Sanderson

Comments: I love everything by Fredrick Backman, but this poignant trilogy (eagerly awaiting translation of 3rd novel) is probably my favorite. It is a story about a small hockey town and how the community we are shapes who we believe and how our desire to protect that identity harms those around us.
Title: Beartown: A Novel
Author: Fredrik Backman

Comments: (special order) This book is all about the relationships that matter: the different ways they can develop, and the things that can get in the way.  Difficult issues are raised, but are approached with a child's eye, and the narrator is clearly loved, which serves as protection for her and for us.
Title: List of Things That Will Not Change
Author: Rebecca Stead

Title: Motherhood So White: A Memoir of Race, Gender, and Parenting in America
Author: Nefertiti Austin

Comments: Classic adventure book - and Newberry Medal winner from 1948 - that's still a fun read!

This is the first of four a part fantasy series that follows a teenage girl as she navigates training to be a starship pilot, battling aliens, and re-integrating herself into society after her family was ostracized due to the actions of her father.
Author: Brandon Sanderson

Comments: This book is great for trying to help our young daughter understand that it is okay to not celebrate Christmas (and that she is not alone in wanting the lights, tree, and presents).
Title: Dear Santa, Love, Rachel Rosenstein
Author: Andrea Troyer

Comments: (special order)
Author: Cornelia Funke

Comments: Always awesome.  The Lord of the Rings is a denser, darker read, but The Hobbit introduces readers to Middle Earth with a quest, lively characters, and a lovable and unexpected hero.
Title: The Hobbit

Comments: The first book in the epic fantasy series that is the source material for Amazon's Wheel of Time TV series which drops on November 19th.
Title: The Eye of the World

Comments: A charming story about how we all feel like quiting sometimes and the role that showing other's gratitude can have in making our work fulfilling. Perfect for talking about those big emotions that come up when we get tired of routine or just talking about the importance of telling others we appreciate how they help us.
Author: Brad Meltzer

Comments: This is the first of 5 books about the Penderwick family - four sisters (think Little Women) and their good friend - and their adventures.  Always at the top of the list when I ask my kids for recommendations: "Soooo good!!" and "Definitely - The Penderwicks!"
Title: The Penderwicks (Penderwicks)
Author: Jeanne Birdsall

Title: Sun Is Kind of a Big Deal

Comments: Yes, the author is Neil Patrick Harris - as in Doogie Howser, MD.  Apparently, he truly is prodigy because in addition to his career in tv, movies, and on stage (drama & musicals!), his first three Magic Misfits books were a huge hit at our house and there's a lot of excitement to read the fourth!

Full of wit and interesting characters. This story is about an unlikely bank robber, who accidentally finds themself holding an apartment full of hostages. This is a pure lighthearted pleasure book that anyone who enjoys people watching will love.
Title: Anxious People
Author: Fredrik Backman

Title: Planting Stories: The Life of Librarian and Storyteller Pura Belpr√©
Author: Anika Aldamuy Denise

Comments: Classic, wacky favorite that many of us probably remember encountering around 4th grade.  According to the middle graders I hang out with - it's still a great read!
Title: The Phantom Tollbooth
Author: Norton Juster

Title: Peter & Ernesto: A Tale of Two Sloths
Author: Graham Annable

Title: Inventing Ourselves: The Secret Life of the Teenage Brain
Author: Sarah-Jayne Blakemore

Comments: A surprisingly fascinating look at the bureaucracy we depend on and a key threat to its survival.
Title: The Fifth Risk: Undoing Democracy
Author: Michael Lewis

Title: Chick and Brain: Smell My Foot!

Comments: Also recommended: Finding Serendipty (book 1) and Blueberry Pancakes Forever (book 3)
Title: A Week without Tuesday
Author: Angelica Banks

Comments: The awesome true story of the bear behind Winnie the Pooh. It is an interesting story in itself but made even greater by the connection to the loved children's books.
Title: Finding Winnie : The True Story of the World's Most Famous Bear
Author: Lindsay Mattick

Comments: Other great books by this author include: Project Mulberry, A Single Shard, Prairie Lotus, The Kite Fighters, Wing & Claw trilogy....
Title: A Long Walk to Water:Based on a True Story
Eyes That Kiss in the Corners
Author: Joanna Ho
